The upÄsaka Zhi Qian, whose courtesy name was Gongming.
Also known as Yue.
He was a person from the great Yuezhi region.
His grandfather Fadut led hundreds of people from the country to take refuge in the Han dynasty during the reign of Emperor Ling of the Han dynasty.
He was appointed as the General of the Central Lang of the Good.
At the age of seven, he rode a bamboo horse and played in a neighbor's house.
He was bitten on the leg by a dog, and the bone was shattered.
The neighbor wanted to kill the dog to take its liver and apply it to the wound.
Yue said:
Heaven has created this creature to guard and bark for people.
If I had not gone to your house, the dog would never have bitten me.
This is my fault, not the dog's.
Even if it could be cured by killing it, it would still be wrong.
How much more so if it is of no benefit to me and I would only incur a great sin by killing it?
Moreover, animals are ignorant, how can they be held accountable?
Because of this, the neighbor was moved by his words and did not kill the dog after all.
At the age of ten, he studied the Book of Han.
At thirteen, he studied the Brahmi script.
He mastered both and was also proficient in the sounds of the six states.
In the beginning, during the reigns of Emperors Huan and Ling, Zhi Chen translated the Dharma canon.
There was Zhi Liang, whose courtesy name was Ji Ming.
He studied under Chen.
Qian also studied under Liang.
He extensively read scriptures and treatises, all of which he understood thoroughly.
He practiced many worldly arts.
He was thin and dark, with small eyes and yellow pupils.
At that time, people said of him:
Zhiliang's eyes are yellow, and although his body is small, he is a treasure of wisdom.
He originally upheld the great Dharma and refined the meaning of the scriptures.
At the end of the reign of Emperor Xian, the Han Dynasty was in great turmoil.
He fled to Wu with several dozen people from his hometown.
On the day of their departure, he only had one robe.
There was a guest who followed him, but it was very cold and he had no robe.
Yue called the guest to sleep together.
In the middle of the night, the guest took his robe and left.
The next morning, his companions asked about the whereabouts of the robe.
Yue said:
Last night, it was taken by a guest.
His companions all said:
Why didn't you report it?
He replied:
If I had reported it, you would have certainly accused me of the crime of theft.
How can it be right to kill a person with a single robe?
Those who heard this from far and near all marveled.
Later, the ruler of Wu, Sun Quan, heard that he was erudite and had talent and wisdom, so he summoned him.
He then asked about the profound meanings in the sutras.
Yue responded to the questions with ease, resolving doubts without fail.
Quan was greatly delighted and appointed him as a doctor.
He was made to assist the crown prince and was greatly favored.
Yue thought that although the great teaching had been practiced, many of the sutras were still in Sanskrit and no one could understand them.
Since he was proficient in both Chinese and foreign languages,
he collected various versions and translated them into the Wu language.
From the second year of the Huangwu era of Emperor Quan, the Guimao year, to the second year of the Jianxing era of Emperor Liang, the Guiyin year, for more than thirty years,
he translated eighty-eight sutras such as the Great Perfection of Wisdom Sutra.
He skillfully grasped the holy meaning and the words were elegant.
He also composed praises for the Bodhisattvas, connected verses, and chanted the three covenants based on the Sutra of the Original Rise of Immeasurable Life.
He annotated the Sutra on Understanding the Origin of Life and Death.
All of these are circulated in the world.
Later, when the prince ascended the throne,
he secluded himself in Qiong'ai Mountain, not engaging in worldly affairs.
He followed the monk Zhu Falan to further refine the five precepts.
All those he associated with were only Å›ramaá¹‡as.
Later, he died in the mountains.
At the age of sixty.
The ruler of Wu, Sun Liang, wrote to the monks, saying: Zhibian Gongming did not seek medical treatment for his illness.
His conduct was pure and simple, and his practice was admirable from beginning to end.
I am deeply saddened and cannot help but feel this way.

Hui went to look and indeed obtained the relics.

When Sun Hao came to power, his laws and edicts were harsh and cruel, and he abolished licentious sacrifices.

Yu returned and praised Senghui's talent and wisdom.

Hao gathered the court officials and welcomed the assembly with horse carriages.
When the assembly took their seats,
Hao asked,

Hui replied,
When the enlightened ruler teaches the world with filial piety and kindness,
then the Vermilion Bird soars and the Elder appears.
When benevolent virtue nurtures beings,
then sweet springs gush forth and auspicious grains grow.

The Book of Poetry says, 'Seeking blessings never goes unrewarded.'

Hao said,
If that is so, then since the Duke of Zhou and Confucius have already clarified this, why is Buddhism necessary?
Hui said, The words of the Duke of Zhou and Confucius briefly show recent traces.
As for the teachings of Buddhism, they fully encompass the profound and subtle.
Therefore, if one does evil, there is long suffering in the hells.

At that time, Hao had no way to refute his words.
Although Hao heard the true Dharma, his nature of being dark and violent could not overcome his cruelty.
Later, he ordered the palace guards to enter the harem to repair the garden.
They found a golden statue several feet tall in the ground and presented it to Hao.
Hao placed it in an impure place and on the eighth day of the fourth month, poured filthy liquid on it.
He laughed with the ministers and took it as entertainment.
Shortly after, his whole body became greatly swollen, and the painful area was even more excruciating. He screamed as if reaching the heavens.
The court astrologer divined and said:
You have offended a great deity.
He immediately prayed to various temples, but the pain became even more intense.
The palace ladies who previously followed the Dharma

Hao raised his head and asked:

The palace ladies then welcomed the image and placed it in the palace hall.

Hao kowtowed on the pillow and confessed his crimes.

The monks invited Hui to speak the Dharma.
Hui then followed him in.
Hao asked in detail about the causes and conditions of offenses and merits.
Hui explained them in a very concise and essential way.
Hao, who had talent and understanding, was delighted and greatly pleased.
He then requested to read the precepts of the monks.

He then took the one hundred and twenty-five fundamental vows and divided them into two hundred and fifty precepts.
In walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, he wished for all sentient beings.
Hao saw the vast and universal compassion and vows, and increased his wholesome intentions.

Shu Lan was intelligent and eloquent from a young age.
He consulted with his two uncles and received the sutras and Dharma. He understood upon hearing them once.
He was good at Sanskrit, Chinese, and also wrote histories.
However, his nature was rather frivolous and he roamed and hunted without restraint.
Once he chased a deer on horseback alone and encountered a tiger. He fell off his horse and broke his right arm.
After a long time, it improved. Later, he rode and ran without stopping.
His mother scolded and admonished him many times, but he did not change.
He became a vegetarian and stopped.
By nature, he loved to drink and would only be happy after drinking three to five liters.
Once he was greatly intoxicated and lay down by the side of the road.
He then entered the gate of Henan County and shouted.
The officials recorded and sent him to the Henan prison.
At that time, Le Guang, the Governor of Henan, was drinking with guests and was already drunk. He said to Shu Lan,
You are a guest. Why do you drink like a student?
Shu Lan said,
When Du Kang brewed wine, everyone in the world drank it together. How could there be any strangers or old acquaintances?
Guang said again,
Drinking wine is fine, but why does it cause madness?
He replied,
Although the people are mad, they are not chaotic.
It is like the governor who is drunk but not mad.
Guang shouted loudly.
A guest at the time said,
How can a foreigner have a white face?
Shu Lan said,
The people of Henan have black faces, but you still don't doubt it.
Why are you surprised that I have a white face?
Then the guests and host admired his quick wit and released him.
Soon after, he died suddenly without illness. After three days, he revived and said,
I entered a vermilion gate with golden and silver halls.
I saw a person who said he was my grandfather.
He told Shu Lan,
I have cultivated goodness for many years and now I receive this reward.
You are a sinner. How can you come here?
At that time, the gatekeeper drove him with a staff into a bamboo grove.
He saw his hunting companions being pecked and bitten by hawks and dogs, howling and crying for help from Uncle Lan.
Uncle Lan ran away for dozens of steps, and encountered a bull-headed man who wanted to strike him.
Uncle Lan said:

The bull-headed man replied:

Soon after, he saw his two uncles come.
They said to the bull-headed man:
The two of us have always received his offerings.
Evil is few, and good is many. He can be spared.
He then followed the Daoist back.
Soon after, he regained consciousness.
Thereupon, he changed his conduct, cultivated kindness, and devoted himself to the scriptures and Dharma.
